p: Gram-positive bacteria are more resistant than Gram-negative bacteria. The thickness and the constitution of their cell walls (cross-linking of peptidoglycan and teichoic acid) could explain their greater resistance to the ultrasonic field [126]. Viruses have a high degree of tolerance [88]. As for enzymes, due to a depolymerization effect, they are recorded to be inactivated via ultrasound. However, the effectiveness of this depolymerization varies [112]. When combined with other antimicrobial methods, ultrasound is also more efficient; thus, various authors have attempted to use it to enhance its impact on microbial and enzyme inactivation in combination with other antimicrobial methods [1], [53]. Beneficial combinations include thermosonication (heat and ultrasound), manosonication (pressure and ultrasound), and [35], [84].
